conversations.content: The Splendor of Carrots: Part One
People like to bend nature to their will; even the crops they farm have been altered over many generations. Their quest to produce better food is a never-ending one.
But were other beings to raise crops, what would they taste like?
Many years ago, a plague of crickets descended upon a village and devoured every last field.
There was no way for the villagers to survive on their stores, so a hunter set out deep into the mountains after game. There he found a farm the likes of which he'd never seen.
Suddenly, a young dragon popped into view. This mountain farm belonged to him, and he welcomed the hunter with a feast of his most prized crop: carrots.
The hunter was amazed; never in his life had he tasted carrots so sweet! If he could get them back to his people, they would surely be saved.
＂I beg you to give me these carrots!＂ the hunter said. The dragon was distressed to learn what had befallen the hunter's people, and quickly agreed to send carrots to the village.
The villagers were overjoyed; not only could they survive, but they would do so eating delicious carrots—for all who tried them agreed they had never tasted the like.
Even a single carrot was enough to fill a grown man up for a night, and thus did the young dragon's produce save the village.
The village and the dragon stayed in touch even after the winter had safely passed. Buoyed by their praise, the dragon devoted himself to growing the perfect carrot.
After much effort, he produced a carrot to top all carrots. It was packed full of nutrients, sublimely sweet, and melted on the tongue. One bite would satisfy any creature.
You can, however, have too much of a good thing—and this carrot's biggest flaw was that it was so very, very good.
The Splendor of Carrots: Part Two
His masterpiece complete, the young dragon offered it to the villagers. The carrots tasted like something from a faerie tale feast, and the villagers roared with approval.
＂Only a dragon could farm such amazing carrots!＂ they cried as one. It was love at first bite...but then their expressions began to change from bliss to bafflement to bitterness.
Everyone wanted to eat more carrots, but they were too full from the first bite to stomach a second one. ＂These are TOO good!＂ they cried. ＂This is torture!＂
No one could eat the carrots anymore. The young dragon felt his heart sink, and he wondered if it might be time to abandon his farm.
Then a new plague of crickets came. ＂No!＂ cried the villagers. ＂They'll destroy our crops again, just like they did last year!＂
The hunter had an idea: he took the dragon's carrots out of the village storehouses and threw them to the hungry crickets.
The pests took one bite of the carrots and flew away sated, leaving the other crops unscathed.
The people cheered, for this was the second time the dragon's carrots had saved their village! But the poor dragon hung his head and said, ＂All that effort for insect repellent!＂
